results.title: Woman in a house
results.brief_description: One of Sue Ford’s earliest films, “Woman in a house” is a feminist critique of domestic female roles. In this short film, a young woman in a suburban house escapes the confinement of her life through surreal dream sequences created with experimental montage techniques. Made in 1972, the film was shown at screenings run by the Melbourne Filmmaker’s Co-op and was one of the most popular films available to rent from the feminist film collective Reel Women, of which Ford was a founding member, in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

results.title: Electric Eskimo (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Frank Godwin and Children's Film Foundation
results.brief_description: He’s an ordinary boy from an ordinary igloo who gets mixed up in an extraordinary scientific experiment. Now he can turn machines on and off just by pointing at them. Rated: G

results.title: Time changes
results.brief_description: “Time changes” is an experimental, self-reflexive film, comprised of footage filmed over four years by Sue Ford and her friends. Described by the artist as being “a documentary about time and change, focusing on four men who were filmmakers and close friends”, the film features friends Stuart Green, Chris Maudson, John Phillips and Paul Reed, as well as Ford, her children Emma and Ben, and artists Richard Brennan, Bonita Ely, Margo Nash and Ashe Venn. Through unscripted dialogue, the friends’ conversations range across topics such as the integrity of filmmaking and creative practice to ways of living and relationships.

results.title: Eighteen Footers
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Richard Mason and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: An exciting and visually beautiful study of yachting on Sydney Harbour, with special reference to the Australian designed eighteen footer, one of the speediest craft of it’s kind in the world. Describes the standard design, how it evolved and a number of variations. Portrays the exhilaration of racing the craft and demonstrates handling techniques

results.title: Election: behind the polls
results.creator_credit: Kate Stone, Matt Scully and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This documentary takes a look behind the scenes at the organising of an election. The role of the Australian Electoral Commission is examined, including such issues as the dissemination of how to vote information, the setting up of the national tally room and polling stations in suburban and remote areas of Australia, arranging postal voting and voting for those who are not able to get to a polling station, and counting of the votes. The role of the Governor General in dissolving the Parliament and associated duties are also examined.

results.title: Election year: electing Australia's federal parliament
results.creator_credit: Martin Cohen, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In showing the conduct of a federal election this film shows how electoral boundaries are fixed, how candidates for election are selected by the political parties and also how votes are counted in elections for both the senate and the representatives

results.title: El nino
results.creator_credit: Peter Sellars, Theatre Musical be Paris-Chatelet, BBC, France 3, LGM and RM Associates
results.brief_description: A modern opera by John Adams, this is the world premier production of “El nino”, staged at the Theatre Musical be Paris-Chatelet, in 2000. Cast consists of: libretto, John Adams, Peter Sellars; soprano, Dawn Upshaw; mezzo-soprano, Lorraine Hunt Lieberson; baritone, Willard White; theatre of voices, Daniel Bubeck, Brian Cummings and Steven Rickards; performed by the Deutsches Symphonie Orchestre Berlin; conducted by Kent Nagano; dancers, Daniela Graca, Nora Kimball and Michael Shumacher. American minimalist composer John Adams represents the Christmas story, in light of the dawn of a new millennium, by interpreting the story described and prophesied in the New Testament of the Bible, as translated by American Richard Latimore. Adams has fragmented this text, added Old English and utilised the Apocrypha, while focusing on the work of female Latin American poets. Adams’ desire is to depict the birth of Christ simultaneously from several different, largely female, points of view. As the singers and dancers perform the work, a video track, created by Peter Sellars and Yreina D. Cervantez, is displayed as a backdrop, poignantly remarking upon the meagre existence of Hispanic Americans who live in the desert area near Los Angeles, between airport and beach. A stunningly original contemporary work, impressively staged and executed.
